author: pandapip1
content:
> ^ also would probably have at least some people design compute-heavy contracts to do it in chunks under 200k gas across multiple txs 

Here was what I considered:
- Making it per transaction origin per transaction
  - Doesn't suffer from the below sybil attacks
  - Will make transactions perhaps too cheap (DDoS risk?)
- Making it per transaction origin per [block/epoch]
  - People would just use multiple accounts to get around this
- Making it per contract per transaction origin per [unit time]
  - Also suffers from the above sybil attack
- Making it per contract per [unit time]
  - The gas would likely run out quickly on commonly-used contracts like Uniswap
  - Might encourage people to deploy many smaller contracts (Maybe a good thing due to sharding???)
    - Would mean that many commonly-used DApps would suddenly get re-engineered
  - How do you split this evenly among all the transactions?

content: Basically, with things like MEV-boost and the execution and consensus clients being split, it's no longer a good assumption that the cost of executing transactions that might be included in a block is split among all ethereum users

author: pietjepuk
content: The consensus client drives the execution client. It can hypothetically drive multiple, but you probably need some additional logic. And I also don't see why the number of execution clients would suddenly _decrease_, if anything it will increase

content: It'd just cause an imbalance in what ops/transactions are cheap, and which ones are not. I don't think it'd make L1 cheaper to use per se, just less transparent/fair, with what txs are effectively "prioritized".
